SourceText: Sometimes it can be hard to find time during the day. Can you think of a time when you’re less busy? For example, maybe it is easier to help out with housework later in the evening when some of the children have gone to sleep. Try to see what works for you!

SourceText: Ask them! By telling your partner you want to help out but don’t know how, you are showing them you care and are interested in being involved. This can also help family members understand each other better.

SourceText: It can be difficult to remember to ask others what they need help with. Once you start offering to help however, others may realise you want to be involved and may ask for help when they need it!

SourceText: This can be hard to remember! Establishing a routine around caregiving or housework tasks can sometimes be helpful. This also lets you talk to your partner or other adults about how to share the workload.
text: This can be hard to remember! Establishing a routine around caregiving or housework tasks can sometimes be helpful. This also lets you talk to your partner or other adults about how to share the workload.

SourceText: It is hard to remember to ask for help. Be kind to yourself if you forget to ask and try again another time. Asking for help and sharing family responsibilities benefits the whole family!
text: It is hard to remember to ask for help. Be kind to yourself if you forget to ask and try again another time. Asking for help and sharing family responsibilities benefits the whole family!

SourceText: It can be difficult to know how to ask for help. Try starting off with suggesting a task you would like help with. Being specific gives your partner a clearer idea of what they can support you with.
text: It can be difficult to know how to ask for help. Try starting off with suggesting a task you would like help with. Being specific gives your partner a clearer idea of what they can support you with.

SourceText: Trying something new can be hard! To make it easier, ask your partner to do it together with you the first few times. Soon you’ll feel more confident doing it on your own!
text: Trying something new can be hard! To make it easier, ask your partner to do it together with you the first few times. Soon you’ll feel more confident doing it on your own!

SourceText: Talk to them! Talking with your partner about how you can share family responsibilities helps both of you understand each other better. It also shows that you care!
text: Talk to them! Talking with your partner about how you can share family responsibilities helps both of you understand each other better. It also shows that you care!

SourceText: It can be difficult to find time during the day sometimes! Can you think of a time when your partner might be less busy, such as early in the morning or later in the evening? Creating a routine around housework can also be helpful.
text: It can be difficult to find time during the day sometimes! Can you think of a time when your partner might be less busy, such as early in the morning or later in the evening? Creating a routine around housework can also be helpful.

SourceText: Sharing responsibilities in the home benefits everyone! While trying something new can feel hard at first, soon you will start to feel more comfortable. If it helps, ask your partner to join you in the beginning!
text: Sharing responsibilities in the home benefits everyone! While trying something new can feel hard at first, soon you will start to feel more comfortable. If it helps, ask your partner to join you in the beginning!

SourceText: Sorry to hear this. What was difficult for you about resolving conflicts between you and your partner?
text: Sorry to hear this. What was difficult for you about resolving conflicts between you and your partner?

SourceText: That is great!
text: That is great!

SourceText: It can be really hard to stay calm when we’re having a disagreement with others. Try to think of something that you can do that might help like taking a couple deep breaths.
text: It can be really hard to stay calm when we’re having a disagreement with others. Try to think of something that you can do that might help like taking a couple deep breaths.

SourceText: It can be easy to forget, but don’t give up! Next time when you start feeling angry, try taking a deep breath before responding. You can also try walking away for a bit if you start feeling frustrated.
text: It can be easy to forget, but don’t give up! Next time when you start feeling angry, try taking a deep breath before responding. You can also try walking away for a bit if you start feeling frustrated.

SourceText: By taking a pause before responding, it can help us stay calm and respond better. When you feel yourself getting angry, try taking a pause. You can do this!
text: By taking a pause before responding, it can help us stay calm and respond better. When you feel yourself getting angry, try taking a pause. You can do this!

SourceText: Sometimes others respond to us negatively when we’re having a disagreement. In these situations, it is sometimes best to walk away for a bit until those involved have calmed down.
text: Sometimes others respond to us negatively when we’re having a disagreement. In these situations, it is sometimes best to walk away for a bit until those involved have calmed down.

SourceText: The sound of a baby crying can be very distressing, especially for a father It is completely natural to want to make it stop. You might also think that you are not a good parent or that your baby is crying to spite you. But all babies cry. It is one of the main ways a baby can tell you that something is wrong.

SourceText: Hello @fields.user_name! Did you know that 3 is a magical number? Breathe in to the count of three and breathe out to the count of three. How do you feel now? Do you feel any different?

SourceText: • Quickly show your face and say "Peek-a-Boo!" or "Hello!" Babies love it!

SourceText: Say to your child “I see a tree, let’s be it”.
text: Say to your child “I see a tree, let’s be it”.

SourceText: Fill it with sand, stones, uncooked rice, beans or any small objects that make an interesting sound.
text: Fill it with sand, stones, uncooked rice, beans or any small objects that make an interesting sound.

SourceText: Get creative! Can you find something colourful or try it with water?

SourceText: Repeat it over and over in a rhythmical way. For example, “My little one, oh little one”.
text: Repeat it over and over in a rhythmical way. For example, “My little one, oh little one”.

SourceText: Create a dance choreography to your children’s favorite songs.

SourceText: For example, “Dance like a monkey”, “Dance like a chicken” or “Dance with just our knees and hips”.
text: For example, “Dance like a monkey”, “Dance like a chicken” or “Dance with just our knees and hips”.

SourceText: Tell @fields.child_nickname that it is okay to feel scared or worried about going back to school. Allow your child to share how they are feeling. It is also normal if your child behaves differently to their usual behaviour. Discuss how going to school might be different and how they can protect themselves from COVID-19. Ask them how their day went and support them if they experienced any difficulties.

SourceText: This game is best when more than 2 people play
text: This game is best when more than 2 people play

SourceText: One person pretends to be doing something – for example, combing hair or making dinner
text: One person pretends to be doing something – for example, combing hair or making dinner

SourceText: Another person asks, “What are you doing?”
text: Another person asks, “What are you doing?”

SourceText: The answer must always be something different than what you are actually doing!
text: The answer must always be something different than what you are actually doing!

SourceText: Blind Dragon
text: Blind Dragon

SourceText: This game is great if you have at least 4 people
text: This game is great if you have at least 4 people

SourceText: Tell the story about a ferocious dragon who lived near a village. He would sneak into the village at night and steal people’s treasures – anything they loved.  Anybody who tried to take their treasure back would be eaten alive.  This continued for many years until the dragon became old, fat, and blind from sitting on his treasure and gazing at the glare of the gold coins. Then the townspeople could try and sneak into his lair and steal back their relatives’ treasure.
text: Tell the story about a ferocious dragon who lived near a village. He would sneak into the village at night and steal people’s treasures – anything they loved.  Anybody who tried to take their treasure back would be eaten alive.  This continued for many years until the dragon became old, fat, and blind from sitting on his treasure and gazing at the glare of the gold coins. Then the townspeople could try and sneak into his lair and steal back their relatives’ treasure.

SourceText: One person plays the dragon. Dragon sits blindfolded or with eyes closed surrounded by a pile of treasure.
text: One person plays the dragon. Dragon sits blindfolded or with eyes closed surrounded by a pile of treasure.

SourceText: If the dragon hears you and points at you, you must go back to the starting place.
text: If the dragon hears you and points at you, you must go back to the starting place.

SourceText: Sit down and close your eyes
text: Sit down and close your eyes

SourceText: How many sounds can you hear? Listen to the sounds inside and outside the room. Count them on your fingers
text: How many sounds can you hear? Listen to the sounds inside and outside the room. Count them on your fingers

SourceText: Find a big piece of paper or cardboard. It needs to be the same length or slightly longer than the height of your child
text: Find a big piece of paper or cardboard. It needs to be the same length or slightly longer than the height of your child

SourceText: Ask your child to draw things that they like and do not like outside of the outline
text: Ask your child to draw things that they like and do not like outside of the outline

SourceText: Let your child make up the next sentence
text: Let your child make up the next sentence

SourceText: Then you make up a sentence
text: Then you make up a sentence

SourceText: Take turns until you have a wonderful new story

SourceText: Here is a comic on how to talk to your child about COVID-19.
text: Here is a comic on how to talk to your child about COVID-19.

SourceText: Child: “Am I going to get coronavirus?”
text: Child: “Am I going to get coronavirus?”

SourceText: Parent: “It is very possible that we will all get coronavirus. But younger people do not normally get very sick.”
text: Parent: “It is very possible that we will all get coronavirus. But younger people do not normally get very sick.”

SourceText: Child: “I am scared…”
text: Child: “I am scared…”

SourceText: Parent: “It is okay to be afraid. We are all a bit scared about this. But we have each other and can do our best to keep ourselves and other people safe and healthy.”
text: Parent: “It is okay to be afraid. We are all a bit scared about this. But we have each other and can do our best to keep ourselves and other people safe and healthy.”

SourceText: Child: “How can we keep safe?”
text: Child: “How can we keep safe?”

SourceText: Parent: “We can wash our hands regularly for 20 seconds. We can also keep a good physical distance away from people. We also need to try to avoid touching our faces as much as possible.”
text: Parent: “We can wash our hands regularly for 20 seconds. We can also keep a good physical distance away from people. We also need to try to avoid touching our faces as much as possible.”

SourceText: Child, “Okay…”
text: Child, “Okay…”

SourceText: Child: “What happens to your body when you get coronavirus?”
text: Child: “What happens to your body when you get coronavirus?”

SourceText: Parent: “To tell you the truth, I don’t know exactly. How about we look on the UNICEF website together?”
text: Parent: “To tell you the truth, I don’t know exactly. How about we look on the UNICEF website together?”

SourceText: 1. Treat each other as equals
text: 1. Treat each other as equals

SourceText: Family and friends might tell you how a husband or a father should act. But both men and women benefit when they talk to each other and make decisions together! For example, next time you’re making a decision, try involving your partner and ask what they think.
text: Family and friends might tell you how a husband or a father should act. But both men and women benefit when they talk to each other and make decisions together! For example, next time you’re making a decision, try involving your partner and ask what they think.

SourceText: Family and friends might tell you how a wife or a mother should act compared to a husband or father.  But both men and women benefit when they talk to each other and make decisions together! For example, next time you’re making a decision, try involving your partner and ask what they think.
text: Family and friends might tell you how a wife or a mother should act compared to a husband or father.  But both men and women benefit when they talk to each other and make decisions together! For example, next time you’re making a decision, try involving your partner and ask what they think.

SourceText: Sharing how we feel and talking about the difficulties we’re facing actually makes everyone in the family stronger! By sharing emotions you can better understand and support each other.
text: Sharing how we feel and talking about the difficulties we’re facing actually makes everyone in the family stronger! By sharing emotions you can better understand and support each other.

SourceText: Sharing your emotions or difficulties you are facing is about making others more aware of how you are feeling. You get to decide how much you want to share. You can also choose to share more at a later time.
text: Sharing your emotions or difficulties you are facing is about making others more aware of how you are feeling. You get to decide how much you want to share. You can also choose to share more at a later time.

SourceText: Talking about our feelings or challenges we’re facing, can help others understand and support you better. Emotions and challenges are a part of life, and learning how to handle these, can help you avoid conflict with loved ones and make life less stressful.
text: Talking about our feelings or challenges we’re facing, can help others understand and support you better. Emotions and challenges are a part of life, and learning how to handle these, can help you avoid conflict with loved ones and make life less stressful.

SourceText: Starting something new can be difficult. Give yourself and others time to get used to it. By setting a good example by sharing your emotions and challenges you’re facing, others will feel start to feel more comfortable sharing too.

SourceText: It’s okay if you don’t want to share at that time. You can choose to share how you’re feeling at a later time once you feel calmer.

SourceText: Parent: "You are a really great dancer! Tell me about why you like it."

SourceText: Child: "All my friends are on it. I have more than 600 likes and 120 followers."
text: Child: "All my friends are on it. I have more than 600 likes and 120 followers."

SourceText: Parent: "I’m proud of how well you dance, Joey. But we need to make sure you are safe on this. I know your friends look at TikTok, but with an open account there are also paedophiles who look at videos of teenagers. Paedophiles are older people who want to attack young children and teens."
text: Parent: "I’m proud of how well you dance, Joey. But we need to make sure you are safe on this. I know your friends look at TikTok, but with an open account there are also paedophiles who look at videos of teenagers. Paedophiles are older people who want to attack young children and teens."

SourceText: Parent: "Let’s look together online at how we can keep this fun for you but also safe. Look – you can make your account private and control who follows you. So you can accept people you know but not strangers. Can we make a rule together that you can use TikTok but with a private account? I trust you to know who to accept!"

SourceText: Children and teens are spending a lot more time online. Here is a comic on how you can create safe and healthy online habits like scheduling time online and offline.
text: Children and teens are spending a lot more time online. Here is a comic on how you can create safe and healthy online habits like scheduling time online and offline.

SourceText: Parent: “Jack, you have been spending a lot of time on your tablet. Why do you think I am concerned about that?”
text: Parent: “Jack, you have been spending a lot of time on your tablet. Why do you think I am concerned about that?”

SourceText: Child: “Um…because I am not doing my schoolwork?”
text: Child: “Um…because I am not doing my schoolwork?”

SourceText: Parent: “Yes, that is one reason. It is important that you make the time for your schoolwork. I also like seeing you being more active. Maybe we can make a household rule about gadget use. What do you think would be a fair limit each day?”
text: Parent: “Yes, that is one reason. It is important that you make the time for your schoolwork. I also like seeing you being more active. Maybe we can make a household rule about gadget use. What do you think would be a fair limit each day?”

SourceText: Child: “Um…two hours a day?”
text: Child: “Um…two hours a day?”

SourceText: Parent: “Hmmm…I think that might be too much time. You have so much else to do every day.”
text: Parent: “Hmmm…I think that might be too much time. You have so much else to do every day.”

SourceText: Child: “How about one hour for fun and one hour for learning?
text: Child: “How about one hour for fun and one hour for learning?

SourceText: Parent: “That sounds reasonable. I would also like you to do your schoolwork before using any gadgets. So from now on, the household rule is that you do your schoolwork before using gadgets and that you can have 1 hour for free time and 1 hour for educational activities. Okay?”
text: Parent: “That sounds reasonable. I would also like you to do your schoolwork before using any gadgets. So from now on, the household rule is that you do your schoolwork before using gadgets and that you can have 1 hour for free time and 1 hour for educational activities. Okay?”

SourceText: Child: “Okay.”
text: Child: “Okay.”

SourceText: Great job! You should be proud of yourself! Research shows that every time you control your anger in front of your child, you increase your child's brain development.
text: Great job! You should be proud of yourself! Research shows that every time you control your anger in front of your child, you increase your child's brain development.

SourceText: It is completely normal to experience this challenge. Next time you feel yourself getting angry try to manage this by taking deep breaths in. This can allow you to relax and reduce stress, which can help with managing your emotions. Every time you do this, you increase your child's brain development!
text: It is completely normal to experience this challenge. Next time you feel yourself getting angry try to manage this by taking deep breaths in. This can allow you to relax and reduce stress, which can help with managing your emotions. Every time you do this, you increase your child's brain development!

SourceText: Here is a comic about spending one-on-one time with your child! Try to follow your child's lead when spending time with them. It will help build self-confidence.
text: Here is a comic about spending one-on-one time with your child! Try to follow your child's lead when spending time with them. It will help build self-confidence.

SourceText: Parent: "I see you are playing quietly with the lego with concentration, Alex."
text: Parent: "I see you are playing quietly with the lego with concentration, Alex."

SourceText: Parent: "Wow! You are building such a tall and strong wall with those legos."
text: Parent: "Wow! You are building such a tall and strong wall with those legos."

SourceText: Child: "It is for cows."
text: Child: "It is for cows."

SourceText: Parent: "It will keep the cow safe!"
text: Parent: "It will keep the cow safe!"

SourceText: Child: "Now you can help me build a house for our family to sleep in!"
text: Child: "Now you can help me build a house for our family to sleep in!"

SourceText: Parent: "This house is going to keep our family warm and dry. You are such a good builder, Alex!"
text: Parent: "This house is going to keep our family warm and dry. You are such a good builder, Alex!"

SourceText: Mothers can have difficult relationships with their teenagers, it can be hard to find pleasure from spending time with them. Instead, we spend a lot of time disciplining them or complaining about how they are behaving.
text: Mothers can have difficult relationships with their teenagers, it can be hard to find pleasure from spending time with them. Instead, we spend a lot of time disciplining them or complaining about how they are behaving.

SourceText: That's okay! You can always type "Help" whenever you want to learn more about how to spend One-on-One Time with your teen. Chat to you later @fields.user_name!

SourceText: You can even try rephrasing back what @fields.child_nickname says when they speak to you. For example, when @fields.child_nickname says, “This math problem is really hard,” you can say, “Yeah, I see that you are finding it difficult.” It shows you are really listening to them and will make them feel supported.
text: You can even try rephrasing back what @fields.child_nickname says when they speak to you. For example, when @fields.child_nickname says, “This math problem is really hard,” you can say, “Yeah, I see that you are finding it difficult.” It shows you are really listening to them and will make them feel supported.
